Award.AwardTitle: Collaborative Research: Artificial Photosynthesis Based on Archaeal Lipids and Proteins for Biofuels

Division.LongName: Div Of Chem, Bioeng, Env, & Transp Sys

Award.AbstractNarration:
Principal Investigator: Parkson Chong
Number: 1437930


Nontechnical Description

The goal of this project is to develop an artificial photosynthesis device to ultimately enable the production of fermentable sugars directly from carbon dioxide and sunlight. These sugars would serve as the renewable feedstock for biofuels production. The concept of reconstituting light harvesting proteins and energy conversion enzymes of photosynthesis into lipid membranes for light driven synthesis of chemical energy carriers required to make sugars from carbon dioxide has been known for many years. However, the low energy conversion efficiency and poor long term stability have hindered further development of this approach. This project will make new artificial photosynthesis devices using novel biomaterials with much improved long-term stability and energy conversion efficiency. The research activities will also provide multidisciplinary project for training graduate and undergraduate students. This is a collaborative project between Temple University, North Carolina State University, and Drexel University.

Technical Description

The goal of this project is to develop an artificial photosynthesis platform that uses bipolar tetra-ether lipids and membrane proteins isolated from thermoacidophilic archaea.integrated into a microfluidic device. The research will study the biochemical and biophysical properties of this artificial photosynthesis platform, and develop a microfluidic device that will serve as a tool to design, fabricate, and evaluate a potentially efficient and durable membrane-based artificial photosynthesis system. This system would support the development of a process that would be capable of converting sunlight, carbon dioxide, and water into carbohydrates for the production of biofuels. The polar lipid fraction E isolated from the archaeon Sulfolobus acidocaldarius will be used as the membrane matrix. These lipids are extremely stable and non-toxic. An ATP synthase will also be isolated from the same thermoacidophile, which is intended to provide stability to the reconstituted protein membrane system and enhance the overall yield of ATP synthesis. Microfluidic chips will be developed to accommodate the bacteriorhodopsin/ATP synthase/archaeal lipid membrane system. The proton pumping efficiency of bacteriorhodopsin in archaeal lipid planar membranes, the ATP synthesis efficiency of the system, and the carbon-fixation efficiency from ATP to glyceraldehyde-3-phosphate will be individually measured to assess the performance of the artificial photosynthesis platform. The research activities will also provide multidisciplinary project for training graduate and undergraduate students.

POR.DRECONTENT:
The ultimate goal of this research is to use the naturally occurring archaea tetraether lipids and proteins as the planar membrane components and a novel micro fluidic device plus a thin film as the platform to generate a highly efficient and durable, membrane-based artificial photosynthesis system. This system would be environmentally friendly and capable of converting sunlight, carbon dioxide, and water into carbohydrates for the production of biofuels such as ethanol. Specifically, we propose to use bipolar tetraether lipids (BTL), especially the polar lipid fraction E (PLFE), isolated from the thermoacidophilic archaeon Sulfolobus acidocaldarius (optimum growth: 75-80oC and pH 2-3) to make the lipid matrix and insert the archaea membrane proteins bacteriorhodopsin (BR) and FoF1-ATP synthase into the BTL planar membranes to provide the light-driven proton pumping and the ATP synthesis, respectively.

 

Intellectual Merit:

(i) We demonstrated that archaea tetraether lipids can form a remarkably stable free-standing planar lipid membrane over a micro-pore (50-250 microns) in a solid thin film on a polydimethylsiloxane (PDMS) or Teflon micro-device. When building the PDMS micro-device, we improved the usage of lithography by developing a double-side molding method which enables the fabrication of a micro-pore-containing PDMS thin film with both sides totally flat. This feature greatly improved the reproducibility of lipid planar membranes over micro-pores in PDMS thin films at a microchip setting. We showed that PLFE free-standing planar membranes over such micro-pores have remarkable membrane stability in comparison to planar membranes made of diester lipids or triblock copolymers. This result is highly significant because conventional diester lipid free-standing planar membranes (or called black lipid membranes) were frequently used in ion channel and membrane protein studies, however, they were known to be extremely unstable, lasting only for less than a few hours. We found that PLFE planar membranes in a micro-device are much more stable, able to retain a constant dielectric property for at least 11 days. (ii) We further demonstrated that PLFE free-standing planar membranes can accommodate the calcium-activated potassium channel MTHK and exhibit its channel opening and closing activities at a calcium concentration as low as 0.1 mM, which suggests that MTHK channel protein becomes even more sensitive to calcium when it is in the tetraether lipid environment. (iii) We also demonstrated that bacteriorhodopsin (BR) can insert into PLFE liposomal membranes and conduct proton pumping upon excitation with green light (500 nm). (iv) We demonstrated that tetraether lipids in microvesicles (~180 nm in diameter) released from the thermoacidophilic archaeon S. acidocaldarius  can also be used to make stable planar lipid membranes. These results (i-iv) together have paved the way to use archaea tetraether lipids and proteins to make membrane-based novel micro-devices for artificial photosynthesis.

 

Broader Impacts:

This research project leads to the fabrication of new and extraordinarily stable free-standing planar membranes on micro-devices by using archaea bipolar tetraether lipids (e.g., PLFE lipids) and by developing novel micro-fabrication techniques. These archaea membrane-based micro-devices may find a wide range of applications such as biosensing, drug screening, environmental decontamination, and, in particular, artificial photosynthesis. Since archaea bipolar tetraether lipids are abundant not only in S. acidocaldarius, but also in virtually all crenarchaeota, which exist in a broad range of habitats and contribute significantly to the total biomass on Earth, this research could also have a profound implication in sustainable biomaterials. This research project has involved multiple disciplines including archaea growth, lipid isolation, protein purification, thin film fabrication, micro-chip fabrication, lithography, electrochemical measurements and biophysical approaches. Thus, this project has been established as a rigorous multidisciplinary training program. During the entire funding period, this project has been used to train two Ph.D. graduate students (Alex Bonanno and Xiang Ren) and several undergraduate students, including two students from historically underrepresented groups, and promote collaborative research among various labs in three different universities (Temple University, Drexel University, and North Carolina State University). For example, Xiang Ren was trained jointly by Dr. P. Chong (lead PI) in the Department of Medical Genetics and Molecular Biochemistry at Temple University and by Dr. J. Zhou (collaborative PI)/Dr. M. Noh in the Department of Mechanical Engineering at Drexel University.
